awd_abstract_narration:
CHS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Electromyography (EMG)-based Assistive Human-Machine Interface Design: Cognitive Workload and Motor Skill Learning Assessment

Over 100,000 people in the United States have upper limb amputations. Such amputations are usually associated with substantial disabilities. Activities of daily living may no longer be possible or require additional effort and time. To restore functional ability as fully as possible, amputee patients use upper-limb prostheses controlled by Electromyography (EMG)-based human-machine interfaces (HMIs). However, over 50% of prosthetic users report device dissatisfaction and abandonment due to frustration in use. In order to increase accessibility and utility of EMG-based assistive HMIs, it is critical to investigate the cognitive workload associated with using these systems for supporting motor skill rehabilitation and activities of daily living. In addition, with differences in individual muscle make-up and control, it is necessary to customize EMG-based assistive HMIs to particular patient conditions. However, at this time, there exists little to no general guidance on what interface control features may be more or less conducive to supporting learning and performance of psychomotor tasks. By testing various control interface prototypes in a validated motor skill learning simulation as well as high-demand, real-time tasks, specifically simulated driving, the investigators seek to provide design guidance for engineers to develop EMG-based assistive HMI technologies for various applications. This project also provides education and training for young industrial, computer science, and biomedical engineering students in assistive technology design and development.

The technical aims of the project are divided into three thrusts including (1) identifying cognitive load costs of EMG-based HMIs using computational cognitive performance models and machine learning algorithms - The developed cognitive workload models will be used for predicting learning potential and performance outcomes of variations of control interface designs, (2) demonstrating fundamental motor skill training through integration of the EMG-based HMI with virtual reality (VR) simulations - In particular, the investigators are interested in assessing whether the difference in cognitive load of using EMG-based HMIs translates to variations in learning potential and retention of psychomotor task skills, (3) translating fundamental motion components trained in the VR psychomotor test to a real-world application by demonstrating the possibility of operational driving control with an EMG-based HMI in a high-fidelity driving simulator - This thrust provides empirical validation for the findings regarding differences in cognitive load of using EMG-based HMIs, as well as the potential for increased learning and operational task performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Outcomes of the Award:

The objective of this research was to create design and engineering guidance for electromyography (EMG)-based assistive human-machine interfaces (HMIs) to support human performance in psychomotor tasks and real-time dynamic control activities. The study findings provide insights on cognitive workload and usability issues associated with prosthetic devices as well as human-centered design strategies. Project outcomes are summarized below.

(1)      We developed cognitive performance models to predict prosthetic user workload, drawing on task analyses and observations of device use. The Cogulator tool was applied for subtask time estimates, memory demand measures, and workload ratings. Studies revealed correlations between these outcomes, participant workload ratings, and physiological response measures. The combination of measures effectively identified differences in cognitive demands across various prosthetic configurations. Additionally, the cognitive models and physiological measures demonstrated potential to detect device usability issues. These findings provide a practical guide for selecting workload measures to improve sensitivity and accuracy in evaluating prosthetics. 

(2)      To inform the design of user-friendly prosthetics, we compared three EMG-based control modes—direct control (DC), pattern recognition (PR), and continuous control (CC)—for effects on user performance, cognitive workload, and perceived usability. We applied two test batteries: the Clothes Pin Relocation Test (CRT) and the Southampton Hand Assessment Procedure (SHAP). Results revealed PR to require precise angle adjustments, while CC reduced workload as compared with DC. Both CC and PR are effective alternatives to DC for task performance and reducing workload. Usability ratings revealed no significant differences across control modes. Hybrid control configurations combining PR and CC, along with multimodal feedback, may reduce prosthetic user workload. Additionally, multitask evaluations are crucial to minimizing bias in configuration comparisons.

(3)      For evaluating upper-limb prosthetic usability, we also developed a test task selection strategy. We reviewed hand function assessment tests and compiled an inventory of upper-limb movements relevant to activities of daily living (ADLs). Overlap was identified between these movements and tasks as part of the CRT and SHAP. A sensitivity analysis revealed the CRT and SHAP to be most effective for assessing usability, as they closely align with high-frequency ADL movements.

(4)      This project also explored the use of machine learning (ML) algorithms to predict cognitive workload in prosthetic device use. In CRT and SHAP tests, we collected user performance and pupillometry data, along with cognitive workload ratings using the NASA Task Load Index. These measures were combined with outcomes from the earlier cognitive performance models as inputs to ML algorithms, including random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), and naive Bayesian (NB) classifiers. Findings revealed the NB and RF algorithms to produce the most accurate classification of cognitive workload during prosthetic device use. These algorithms provide valuable tools for clinicians and manufacturers to assess cognitive workload. 

(5)      Virtual reality (VR) has not been previously explored for prosthetic device usability and cognitive workload assessment. We developed realistic simulations of hand function/procedure assessment tests and compared them with physical device tests using qualitative and quantitative measures. Results showed consistent patterns across VR and physical testing, indicating that VR can effectively predict user workload and usability responses. Additionally, results showed VR simulations reduce user perceived workload and increased usability compared to physical tests, highlighting VR potential as a valuable tool for user prosthetic testing and training. 

(6)      We integrated an EMG-based HMI with commercially available driving simulator software. This enabled users to perform basic driving tasks and tactical maneuvers (passing, making turns at intersections). The HMI did not outperform conventional hand-steering; however, the study identified cognitive workload and usability issues to guide future research in enhancing EMG-based HMI systems. 

(7)      We also developed a Human Performance Model for Upper-Limb Prosthetic Devices (HPM-UP). The model integrates qualitative measures of prosthetic learnability and user satisfaction with quantitative measures of task error rate, memory load and efficiency to predict overall device usability. An experiment demonstrated model outcomes to correlate more strongly with established HCI usability measures than task performance data alone. Available in RStudio via GitHub, this model provides clinicians and researchers with a valuable tool to assess and compare commercial prostheses.

Broader Impacts:

The outcomes of this research extend beyond intellectual/research contributions to practical applications in assistive technology, education, and user-centered design. Impacts include:

(1) Enhanced Rehabilitation and Daily Living Support: This research advanced the potential of EMG-based HMIs for rehabilitating motor skills and supporting daily task performance by persons with upper-limb amputations.

(2) Applications of Realistic Virtual Testing and Training Environments: Simulations of psychomotor tasks were used to evaluate usability of EMG-based HMIs. These systems support device design, user training for prosthetic applications, and promote user long-term device adoption.

(3) Education and Training for Students: The research provided graduate and undergraduate students hands-on training in EMG-based HMI design, cognitive workload analysis, and VR simulation development, preparing them for careers in assistive technology innovation.
